docs.title: GEE Protocols: Technical Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the internal protocols repository for the GEE project. This documentation serves as a centralized source of truth for environment setup, version control standards, and development workflows.

docs.title: 🛠️ Quick Access
docs.text:
Select a module to view the standardized procedures:

Module Description Status Git & GitHub Version control, branching and commits. ✅ Stable VS Code IDE configuration and extensions. ✅ Updated Development Python environment and dependency management. 🚧 In Progress

docs.title: 📌 General Guidelines
docs.text:
To maintain project consistency, all contributors must follow these core principles:

  1. Standardization: Use the configurations defined in the VS Code Guide.
  2. Traceability: Every change must be linked to a descriptive commit.
  3. Documentation: Keep protocols updated as the environment evolves.

Note on Updates

This documentation is automatically updated via GitHub Actions. Always ensure you are viewing the latest version.

Last updated: December 2025

docs.title: Git and GitHub
docs.text: <<<<<<< HEAD

docs.title: Git and GitHub: Technical Guide for Version Control
docs.text: This document establishes a standardized workflow for version control, focusing on fundamental principles of software traceability and collaboration.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Version control is a system designed to record changes to files over time, ensuring reproducibility and historical integrity. Git serves as the distributed version control engine, while GitHub provides the infrastructure for remote hosting and collaborative development.

docs.title: Core Objectives
docs.text:
• Traceability: Comprehensive record of every modification.
  • Collaboration: Parallel development workflows for research teams.
  • Redundancy: Cloud-based backup of the complete project history.
  • Integrity: Ability to revert to verified states without data loss.

docs.title: Installation and Setup
docs.text:
Select the appropriate tab for your operating system environment:

WindowsmacOSLinux
  1. Download the installer from the official Git website.
  2. During installation, select Git from Git Bash only.
  3. Choose MinTTY as the default terminal emulator.

Verify the installation via terminal: 

git --version

It is recommended to use the Homebrew package manager: 

brew install git

Alternatively, install Xcode Command Line Tools: 

xcode-select --install

Use the package manager corresponding to your distribution:

# Ubuntu / Debian
sudo apt update && sudo apt install git

# Fedora
sudo dnf install git

# Arch Linux
sudo pacman -S git

docs.title: Phase 1: Local Initialization
docs.text: The primary goal is to initialize a tracking environment for a specific directory.

docs.title: 1. Identity Configuration
docs.text:
Global parameters must be set to attribute commits to the correct researcher:

```bash git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com" =======

docs.title: 📘 The Definitive Git & GitHub Guide: A Didactic Protocol
docs.text: This guide establishes the standard workflow for version control, focusing on the purpose (the why), the execution (the how), and the validation (the check).

docs.title: 🧱 Level 1: The Foundation
docs.text: Goal: Transform a standard folder into an intelligent repository that tracks every change.

docs.title: 1. Identity Configuration 🔑
docs.text: Before recording any history, Git needs to know who the author is. - Action: - git config --global user.name "Your Full Name" - git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com" - The "Why": Every "save" (commit) is signed. Without this, Git cannot attribute changes to you. - Verification: Run git config --list to confirm.

docs.title: 2. Initialization & Essential Setup 🏗️
docs.text: Prepare the environment and set the rules for what Git should track. - Action: - git init: Starts the Git engine in your folder. - echo ".venv/" > .gitignore: Creates a "shield" to ignore heavy system folders or sensitive files. - echo "# My Knowledge Base" > README.md: Creates the project's "front page." - The "Why": The .gitignore prevents "junk" files from cluttering your repository, while the README provides context for anyone viewing your work.

docs.title: 3. The Saving Cycle (Add & Commit) 🔄
docs.text:
• Action:
  • git status: Check what Git sees. ✅
  • git add .: Place all changes in the "Staging Area" (the outbox). 📦
  • git commit -m "Initial commit": Permanently record the snapshot. 💾
  • Verification: If git status says "nothing to commit, working tree clean", your first milestone is complete!

docs.title: ☁️ Level 2: Connecting to the World
docs.text: Goal: Sync your local machine with GitHub for cloud backup and sharing.

docs.title: 1. Building the Bridge 🔗
docs.text: Connect your local folder to your GitHub repository address. - Action: git remote add origin https://github.com/abrantes-scihub/knowledgebase.git - Verification: git remote -v should show your GitHub URL.

docs.title: 2. The First Push 🚀
docs.text:
• Action:
  • git branch -M main: Renames the default branch to the modern standard "main."
  • git push -u origin main: Sends the files and creates a permanent link.
  • The "Why": The -u flag links your local branch to the remote one so that future pushes only require the command git push.

docs.title: 🌿 Level 3: Parallel Development (Branches)
docs.text: Goal: Create "parallel universes" to test ideas without breaking the main project.

docs.title: 1. Creating Branches 🎋
docs.text:
• Action: git checkout -b feature-name
  • The "Why": It's like taking a photocopy of your project. If the new feature works, you merge it; if it fails, you delete the branch with zero risk.

docs.title: 2. Merging 🤝
docs.text:
• Action: git checkout main then git merge feature-name.
  • Didactic Tip: Always ensure your "main" branch is clean before merging a feature into it.

docs.title: ⚡ Level 4: Mastery & Recovery
docs.text: Goal: Manage complex scenarios and undo mistakes like a professional.

docs.title: 1. The Pause Button (Stash) ⏸️
docs.text:
• Action: git stash hides your current work. git stash pop brings it back.
  • The "Why": Perfect for when you need to switch branches immediately but aren't ready to commit your current work.

docs.title: 2. Emergency Recovery 🛡️
docs.text:
• Action:
  • git commit --amend: Fixes a typo in the last commit message.
  • git reset --hard HEAD: Discards all current changes and returns to the last saved state.

    502f1cae15fed7b0b4c1cc6885bfcfa2d3d74709

docs.title: Visual Studio Code: Optimization and Standards
docs.text: This guide outlines the configuration protocols for Visual Studio Code to ensure a standardized development environment across different Unix-like and Windows platforms.

docs.title: Technical Overview
docs.text: Visual Studio Code (VS Code) serves as the primary integrated development environment (IDE) for this project, utilizing a modular architecture based on extensions and workspace-specific configurations.

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text:
Select your operating system to view specific installation and path configuration protocols:

WindowsmacOSLinux
  1. Download the System Installer from the official VS Code site.
  2. During installation, ensure the following options are enabled:
    • Add to PATH (requires shell restart).
    • Register Code as an editor for supported file types.
  3. Verify via terminal: 
    code --version
  1. Download the .zip archive for Apple Silicon or Intel.
  2. Move Visual Studio Code.app to the /Applications folder.
  3. Open the Command Palette (Cmd+Shift+P) and type: Shell Command: Install 'code' command in PATH.

Verify via terminal: 

code --version

For Debian/Ubuntu based systems: 

sudo apt update
sudo apt install software-properties-common apt-transport-https wget
wget -q [https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc](https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc) -O- | sudo apt-key add -
sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] [https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode](https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode) stable main"
sudo apt update
sudo apt install code

docs.title: Core Extensions Protocol
docs.text:
To maintain project consistency, the following extensions are considered mandatory:

  • Python: Comprehensive support for the language (Pylance, Debugging).
  • Material Icon Theme: Visual standardization of the file tree.
  • MkDocs Material: Support for documentation preview and syntax.
  • GitLens: Enhanced authorship traceability.

docs.title: Editor Configuration (settings.json)
docs.text:
Recommended global parameters for academic readability:

```json { "editor.fontSize": 14, "editor.fontFamily": "'Fira Code', 'Consolas', monospace", "editor.fontLigatures": true, "editor.formatOnSave": true, "editor.renderWhitespace": "boundary", "files.insertFinalNewline": true, "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true }
